quiz.pack.title: Quiz on Distance Preserving Linear Transformations

question.para: Does a shear transformation of the plane preserve distances?

info.para: In the picture above, consider the effect of shearing on the vector \StdBss{2}

answer.para: A shear transformation is distance preserving.
A shear transformation is not distance preserving.

info.para: Correct! - To see why a shear map S\from \RNr[2]\to \RNr[2] is, in general, not distance preserving, consider the vector \Vect{n} with respect to which we are shearing (in the picture above, this is \StdBss{2}). It has length 1, and gets transformed into the vector \Vect{n}+\Vect{s}, where \Vect{s} is the shear vector. So, unless \Vect{s}=\Vect{0}, the shear transformation increases the length of some vectors. Therefore it is not distance preserving.

question.para: Does the dilation transformation below preserve distances?

answer.para: No! D does not preserve distances

info.para: Correct! – D increases the distance between any two points by a factor of 3. Therefore D does not preserve distances.

question.para: Does a reflection of \RNr[3] about a plane passing through the origin preserve distances?

answer.para: No! This reflection does not preserve distances.

question.para: Does a projection of the plane \RNr[2] onto a line through the origin preserve distances?

answer.para: Yes, such a projection preserves distances
No, such a projection does not preserve distances

info.para: Correct! – A projection can reduce certain distances. For example: in the picture above, consider the vector \Vect{c}. Its length is positive. But it projects to the zero vector. Therefore the projection does not preserve all distances.
